title: Fort Glass
text:
Fort Glass was a stockade fort built in July 1813 in present-day <a href="Clarke%20County%2C%20Alabama">Clarke County, Alabama</a> during the <a href="Creek%20War">Creek War</a> (part of the larger <a href="War%20of%201812">War of 1812</a>).
History.
Background.
The <a href="Creek%20War">Creek War</a> of 1813 began as a civil war between supporters of the <a href="Creek%20people">Creek</a> national government and a rebel faction called <a href="Red%20Sticks">Red Sticks</a>. Americans, who were already engaged in the <a href="War%20of%201812">War of 1812</a> against <a href="United%20Kingdom%20of%20Great%20Britain%20and%20Ireland">Britain</a>, joined the Creek war in the hope of breaking Creek power and depriving the British of a potential ally. 
The American settlers became fearful after these Creek attacks and were unsure if the United States would protect them due to fact they were <a href="Squatting">squatters</a> on public lands. To protect themselves the settlers built temporary stockades, and most were named for the person who owned the land the stockade was built on. After the Creek War, most of these forts were dismantled.
Creek War.
Fort Glass was built in 1813 by and named for Zachariah Glass. The fort was rectangular in shape, sixty yards by forty yards, and constructed of hewn pine logs.
After completion, <a href="Samuel%20Dale">Samuel Dale</a> stopped at Fort Glass on his way to <a href="Georgia%20%28U.S.%20State%29">Georgia</a>. The occupants asked him to stay and he was given command of Fort Glass for a brief time.
En route from <a href="St.%20Stephens%2C%20Alabama">Fort St. Stephens</a> to intercept <a href="Peter%20McQueen">Peter McQueen</a>'s party of Red Sticks who were returning from <a href="Pensacola%2C%20Florida">Pensacola</a> with supplies, Colonel James Caller stopped at Fort Glass after passing through <a href="Jackson%2C%20Alabama">Jackson</a>. Upon leaving Fort Glass, additional reinforcements joined Caller including a party of volunteers from Fort Glass led by Dale. These volunteers participated in the <a href="Battle%20of%20Burnt%20Corn">Battle of Burnt Corn</a> on July 27, 1813.
After the Battle of Burnt Corn, General <a href="Ferdinand%20Claiborne">Ferdinand Claiborne</a> feared swift revenge on part of the Red Sticks. Claiborne sent Colonel Joseph Carson with two hundred mounted soldiers to Fort Glass as reinforcements to protect the settlers in the surrounding area. These soldiers arrived at Fort Glass on August 10, 1813. Soon after their arrival, the soldiers began construction of a new fort located two hundred and twenty-five yards northwest of Fort Glass. This new fort was named Fort Madison in honor of then-President <a href="James%20Madison">James Madison</a>. Soldiers remained in Fort Glass and Fort Madison, but Fort Madison was made the headquarters for the surrounding military district after it was constructed. This district included the territory between the <a href="Alabama%20River">Alabama</a> and <a href="Tombigbee%20River">Tombigbee Rivers</a>.
After the Red Stick attack on <a href="Fort%20Sinquefield">Fort Sinquefield</a>, the settlers who occupied Fort Sinquefield fled to Fort Glass and Fort Madison for protection. Ten men from Fort Glass went to Fort Sinquefield to recover bodies of the slain and to assist with burials. After news of the Fort Sinquefield attack reached Fort Glass, Jeremiah Austill traveled by horseback to inform General Claiborne at <a href="Mount%20Vernon%2C%20Alabama">Mount Vernon</a>, stopping overnight at <a href="Fort%20Carney">Fort Carney</a>.
Present day.
Nothing remains at the site of Fort Glass today. In 1858, the Fort Madison Church was built on the site of Fort Glass. The approximate site of Fort Glass has been identified and archaeological surveys have been made of the area, but no defining features have been found.
